Patch Set 21:

(4 comments)

Patch Set 21:

(4 comments)
Are we going to get any test cases for any of this code?

We have a functional tests for VM. Making it available outside is a topic for other discussion though.
No unit tests are available at the moment.

I don't find this a particularly acceptable answer.  You're going to be adding a bunch of code and nobody has any way to test it except your team?  How can anyone contribute to it?  How are you going to be able to accept even trivial fixes to this code without slowing down the project by saying "I need to test this first"?

New code should have unit tests at a minimum.  Integration tests in openbmc-test-automation is an additional bonus.
Unit tests are "under construction" (i.e. we've already started implementation) and will be available as soon as possible. We're just not ready to publish them yet.
That is good, but I would prefer we don't accept this code into upstream until unit tests are available.  Those should be co-developed with the original code.

We use it for debugging to see events and states transitions printed out "human readable". 
BasicEvent is just for avoid duplication of name field. With removed virtual function I would prefer the rest to leave it as is to avoid complication of such simple thing.

> BasicEvent is just for avoid duplication of name field. 

This seems significantly worse than just putting a name string in each element.  BasicEvent is initialized with __FUNC__, which is already present in the logger.  You could get the same result by just putting a log statement in each constructor.
__func__.  __FUNCTION__ is a deprecated GCC extension.  __func__ is part of the C++ standard.
Sure, I will change to __func__ or even use boost/function_name.hpp for better portability.
Done, used __func__.
What???  Why do you even have BasicEvent if you're going to use variant instead?  You've now got the overhead of _both_ a virtual function table AND the variant-visitor stuff.  Pick one.
Removed virtual destructor. See answer above.
Deduplicating a Name field isn't really a sufficient reason to take the overhead of both variant and inheritence.
IOC?
Will change.
Done
emplace this.
ok
Done
Use std.
I will change to std::unordered_map.
Done
Taking a pause from reviewing here...
FYI, I'll be OOO till 01/10/22.
Can you start by basing it on this patch so we get some tidy static analysis run on the code?  https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/jsnbd/+/65440
Why is this a template.  Isn't EventT always going to be event?

Overall this patchset adds a ton of complexity that IMO is unjustified.  It's adding a whole state machine with a lot of abstraction, but fails to actually accomplish anything with it.  It would help a lot if we could start with a simple set of code that implements a basic mount point, then adds complexity as it's needed.  I had a lot of trouble reading this patchset given it doesn't really seem to accomplish anything useful (at least in this patch).

This patch series continues to be very difficult to review, given that I'm 3 patchsets and several thousands of lines of code into the review, and we still haven't accomplished anything that's of use to a virtual media system.

Please don't name the same class in two different namespaces.  It confuses search.


Also, this isn't an interface as it's written, so it's really unclear how it should be used.
Why catch this and rethrow it rather than just use the throwing version of create_directory?
